Situation1: This is the last weekend before the partner relocates abroad for months.
Situation2: Many prospects ask detailed technical questions about the new service that the script only partially addresses.
Story: I glance at the clock—Saturday afternoon, the last weekend before Alex leaves for months. He’s waiting in the living room, our favorite movie queued up, his hand patting the couch, eyes hopeful. I promised him this day, just us, no distractions. But my phone buzzes again. My manager’s message flashes: “We need you on the line. High-value prospects today. Handle all objections, answer every question.” I slip into the bedroom, headset on, laptop open. The calls come fast. Customers want details about the new service—technical specs, compatibility, things my script barely covers. I fumble for answers, my mind half with Alex, half with the insistent voices in my ear. Guilt gnaws at me. I hear Alex laugh at the TV, then go quiet. I want to be there, to soak up every minute before he’s gone, but the pressure to perform at work is crushing. My heart pounds as I stare at the closed door, torn between the person I love and the job that needs me.
